title: 105_hr4719
content: The Act may be cited as the "International Financial Institution Reexamination and Review Commission Act of 1998". It establishes the International Financial Institution Reexamination and Review Commission. The International Financial Institution Reexamination and Review Commission is established with twelve members appointed by various leaders within 45 days of the Act's enactment. The International Financial Institution Reexamination and Review Commission is established with twelve members appointed based on qualifications and affiliations. Members serve for the life of the Commission, and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission advises Congress on the future role of international financial institutions, the World Trade Organization, and the Bank for International Settlements. It examines the impact of globalization, current policies, cooperation among institutions, and other relevant matters. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, gather necessary information, and select a Chairman to make recommendations on various matters. The Commission, under subsection (b)(1), will choose its Chairman and hold meetings as called by the Chairman. Upon termination, the Commission will submit a report to the Secretary of the Treasury and relevant committees with recommendations on policy goals and changes to international financial institutions. The Commission will discuss monitoring tools, global standards, possible mergers or abolition of international financial institutions, and necessary changes to stabilize currencies and promote trade liberalization. The Commission will terminate 6 months after submitting a report to the Secretary of the Treasury. The Commission will terminate 6 months after the first meeting, and the President will report on the feasibility of implementing recommendations within three months of receiving the Commission's report. Annual reports on steps taken internationally will be submitted for three years after the Commission's termination. The Commission will report on the feasibility of implementing recommendations within three months of receiving the report, and annual reports on international steps taken will be submitted for three years after the Commission's termination. Relevant international institutions and fora will implement these recommendations.
